ygData.subject: Re: Ken's Question to Dawkins, Wolpert, and Jones at GECCO 2007
ygData.msgSnippet: I m not up on CPPN theory, but the inherent modularity is excellent news.  As you mentioned, the lack of an need to design modularity but to allow it to emerge

I'm not up on CPPN theory, but the inherent modularity is excellent
news.  =
As you mentioned, the lack of an need to design modularity but
to allow it =
to emerge is presumably closer to the biological scenario.

-Kirk



--- In=
 neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green" <locster01@...> wrote:
>
> On 05/01/20=
08, newtwist2000 <rkdelisle@...> wrote:
> >
> >  A bit of an aside, the abi=
lity to establish modularity may be a
> >  significant next step.  Most EC =
applications are limited in this
> >  capacity.  I'm not sure if NEAT is fu=
lly compatible with
modularity or
> >  not - thoughts?
> 
> Just on this po=
int - I would say that the ability of CPPN's to
> generate repeated structu=
res and elaboratations on those repeated
> structures means that modularity=
 (re-use) is inherently part of the
> CPPN model.  I know this is a central=
 part of why CPPNs were devised
> but I'm not sure that the word modularity=
 has come up before when
> discussing CPPNs.
> 
> Anyway it's another nice =
characteristic of CPPNs because it means we
> no longer have to explicitly =
write code to allow modularity.
> 
> Colin.
>
